climbs.name: Workin' For The Weekend
climbs.fa: Jared Hancock, Karla Carandang, Jenny Wagner, Mark Ryan 2005

content.description: Climb the moderate slab to get to the first crux section as the wall steepens... This crux can be done to the right of the bolt (techy) or the left (powerful) at about the same grade... above this you get a little rest the one more crux pulling an overlap and through a notch(an undercling may help)... from there it eases up a bit till you are at the chains...
content.location: Just left of Return of the Manimal 5.10d...

climbs.name: Trundling Kentucky
climbs.fa: Skip Wolfe, Jeff Colombo, Mark Ryan

content.description: This route has a little of everything from face moves, jugs and a mantle to get you to the anchors. Clip the anchors high and to the left on the ledge.
content.location: About 15 feet right of Sweet Jane

content.description:
easy 5.5 climbing to a short corner.

Plug a medium cam and make the one slaby move and cruise to the anchors.
content.location: This is the second route on the wall under the roof.  It's start is next to Flutterby Blue

content.description:
Formerly one of the few interesting trad lines at Bruise Brothers, Sweet Jane has now been retrobolted as a somewhat less remarkable sport route.

Follow a somewhat broken and nicely-featured dihedral up to a short left-leaning hand crack toward the top.  Pull the crack and finish at the anchors under the big roof.
content.location: Starts just left of Hey There Fancy Pants.  Rap from the anchors.

climbs.name: Stay Off the Radio Jeff!
climbs.fa: Chad Maurer, Mark Ryan, Jeff Colombo, 2011

content.description: This route is the bolted line to the left of Bee's Business. Ascend a slabby section to a small roof, navigate the roof and continue up the slab to the top.
content.location: Bolted line to the left of Bee's Business.

content.description: This route ascends the overhanging pocketed face out the middle of the mini-amphitheater. Solve the thin cruxy sequence between the 1st and 2nd bolts, then swim up 5.10 jugs to a Fixe ring anchor below the final roof.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a Fixe Ring Anchor
content.location: Walk 3 minutes past the main Bruisebrothers Wall to a small amphitheater.

climbs.name: Send Me on My Way
climbs.fa: Jared Hancock, Karla Carandang, Jenny Wagner, Mark Ryan - 2005

content.description: Feels easier than 5.9, easy clipping stances, nice jugs.  Very good climb.
content.location: Located at the opposite end as the entrance to Bruise Brothers wall.  It is where Rat Stew and the other sport climbs are.

content.description: Climb a low-angle slabby start to the more vertical wall.  Ascend the steeper via reachy moves and big holds to the roof just before the anchors.  Pull through the roof to arrive at the chains.  Good route.
content.location: The far right end of the wall.  This is the third route from the right.

content.description: An extension to CH4.  Climb up to chains on CH4 and continue up through large bulging roof for 3 bolts to top chains.  Really fun and bouldery.
content.protection: 3 more bolts after CH4, then chains.
content.location: Extension of CH4.

content.description: Start from the boulder or ground and ascend poor open hand holds to an anchor.
content.location: just left of Redeye Brew.  These two short climbs are found at the first trail cut off to the left while heading up to Bruise Brothers.  It may be easy to miss.

content.description: Solid pockets and very nice underclings climb to a nice top out on a large ledge.
content.location: Second bolted route on the Bruise Brothers wall.

climbs.name: Rat Stew
climbs.fa: Jared Hancock, Joel Bruhn, Tim Powers - 2004

content.description: Nice moderate sport route.  Climb up the low-angle slabby start on balancy little knobs.  Then climb up the steeper upper wall using good big holds.
content.protection: Bolts; bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: This is the farthest route to the right on the wall.

content.description: Easy trad romp to the disconnected blocks below the two bolts.  Mantle the ledge.  Clip the bolts and head to the anchors.
content.protection: Small to medium cams and nuts, two bolts at top.
content.location: Route is located right after the offering.  It starts in a right leaning short dihedral.  It continues over the bulges you see above your head.

content.description: A broken wondering crack system to a small ledge to a right arching crack to the anchors of Red Eye Brew
content.location: 40' to the right of Dirt In Eye.

climbs.name: The P. Heist Rockway to Heaven

content.description: Crack system that begins from the base of "The Offering" up and right to chain anchor on "Get on the Good Foot".

climbs.name: Ohio Climbing
climbs.fa: Zac Kroeger, Mark Ryan, JJ Jones, Bob Kroeger

content.description: Climb large plates and pockets to a short crux near the anchors.
content.location: On the right part of the cliff. This route is to the left of Workin for the Weekend.

climbs.name: The Offering
climbs.fa: Dennis Rice, Mike Susko, Tim Powers

content.description: Easy climbing leads to roof pulling on somewhat positive holds.  Make a long reach up to the next hold over the roof, don't fall the last bolt is a long way down.  I used a #4 camalot below the roof, to protect those moves.  It's still not over once you get over the roof.
content.location: Main route on prominent corner with small roof system.  To the right of Don't Take Yer Guns to Town.

content.description: Start on a right-facing flake, then pull boulder problem through the roof, and up easier ground to the chains.
content.location: On the first wall encountered upon reaching the cliff.  To the right of "Jungle Trundler" and "Hey There Fancy Pants".

content.description:
A popular route that is super fun and a good example of the 5.11a grade in my opinion...

Start on thin holds climbing past a scar in the rock to better holds for an awkward move or two and then a rest looking up at a shallow corner with a crack in it... Jam or layback a few moves in the crack to more moderate but fun climbing to a mantel and the chains...
content.location: Between Fancy Pants 5.10c and Little Viper 5.10b...

content.description:
This short trad line may be worth doing if you happen to have your rack with you at this predominantly sport area.

Finesse your way up a short flaring crack to a horn.  Continue up the thin, left-leaning crack to the anchors for A-Beano.
content.protection: Small cams and nuts.  Shares anchors with A-Beano.
content.location: Starts just left of Don't Take Yer Guns to Town.

content.description: Start by climbing up a flake to slightly easier ground above.  Good fun.
content.location: One of the first routes encountered after reaching the wall.  Just to the left of "Jungle Trundler".

content.description: Surmount the bulge at the first bolt with the help of a slopey sidepull pinch. The route eases up after the first bolt.
content.location: Approximately 100 ft right of “Rat Stew”.

content.description: Right of “Guardians of Gaia” is another route that has a slopey crux at the first bolt. This one is a bit more desperate and requires some technique and balance along with some sloper squeezing.
content.protection: 4 bolts + shared Fixe double ring anchor with the previous route
content.location: Right of “Guardians of Gaia”.

content.description:
Climb the plated features to a crack system, and chimney behind a large flake. Standing on top of the flake you can choose to go left onto a ledge and climb straight up, clipping two bolts (Put The Best Foot Forward) or continue angling right out a crack system towards send me on my way. Top out a large ledge where you'll find a set of rappel anchors or end on Send Me on My Way if no other parties are occupying that anchor.

The rock quality deteriorates when Get on the Good Foot angles out right, be careful not to knock rocks on those below or choose to clip up the bolts and finish on Put the Best Foot Forward for better rock quality.
content.protection: Regular modern rack with some TCUs
content.location: Starts as for Put The Best Foot Forward 5.8 and finishes to the right of that route and left of Send Me On My Way 5.9-...

content.description: Traverse in to the arete from either side, or attempt the bouldery, reachy direct start for bonus points and a jump in the difficulty rating. Then go up.
content.location: Flutterby Blue is the first sport route on the left end of the main Bruise Brothers crag. From the trail, head left up a slight rise to a small alcove behind some trees.

climbs.name: Don't Take Yer Guns to Town

content.description:
The guidebook calls this a "one-move wonder," but if you don't have some gas left to get to the anchors after the roof, your next move will be straight down.

Starting at a short dihedral, climb up and right to easy ground that leads up to a roof.  Clip the bolt on the lip, then hand-traverse right before making a reachy move to pull the roof (crux).  Continue straight up past the last bolt to anchors that are invisible until you're almost on top of them.
content.location: Starts about 10' right of A-Beano.

content.description: A dirty hand sized crack through a tree ledge. The name is a pretty good description of the experience.
content.location: As the approach trail meets the wall for Bruise Brothers left flank, this route will be just to the left. A Tag marks its beginning.

climbs.name: Critters on the Cliff
climbs.fa: Jared Hancock, Tim Powers, Tony Panozzo, Karla Carandang - 2004

content.description: A lower-angle slabby start gives way to a steeper upper wall.  Climb through a short section of overhanging thin crack and continue to the chains using big holds.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the wall.  This is the second route from the right end of the wall.

content.description: Another short but fun route that is well sheltered from rain... similarly to A-Beano you start with the crux and go on to more moderate stuff but unlike that route you will hit one more challenging move right before the anchor...
content.location: Just left of A-Beano under the roof...

content.description:
Fun bolted route just to the left of Sweet Jane. Climbs a little bit easier and is a little more fun than Sweet Jane.

According to Jeff Colombo, the route got it's name from the large bees nest that usually forms near the bottom of the route each summer. Glad I was there in the spring!
content.location: Route just to the left of Sweet Jane.

content.description: Hard first move.  Easy climbing to anchors.  Last move is easier if you are taller.
content.location: Route is located near the entrance to the Bruise Brothers Wall.  It is one of the initial short routes, before you pass The Offering.
